Modifier.noteText: Idle Break Setup|Entering the "Idle with IdleBreak Timer" state will start a 4 second|timer after which the input Action is set to idleBreak.|This will cause the "Idle Break Start" state to be selected.|The force-follow links on that state will start a random animation.|After playing finished, the "Idle Break Exit" state is entered, which|is not attached to the SetInput Modifier - which causes the Action|input to be reset. |This makes "Idle with IdleBreak Timer" the best matching state again.

Ladder climbing consists out of a climb loop animation and an |animation to exit the lasser at the top.|The Climb Loop is set to ManualUpdate - the game code handling the| ladder climbing is updating the animation time instead of the |animation system according to the keyboard or controller input.|See the function "ProcessMovementOnLadder" inside GameDLL |in PlayerMovement.pp.||The Output "OnLadder" is queried from the code to check whether |the graph is still playing one of the ladder animations. If it is not set, the code will terminate the ladder movement.

The Purpose of HUBs is to reduce the number of links in the graph.|Less ilnks mean faster graph pathfinding, but it also makes it easy |to set up transitions for a whole groups of animations into another.|The graph will always choose the shortest path through the graph.|Since all Idle states are connected to the Idle Hub, the graph has to pass through this state |on its way to a different state. Setting up a transition on this hub will cause all idle states to use this transition automatically - no need to explicitly link each individual state.|You can always do a direct link if you want a specific transition between two states, or none at all.|See the Jumping View for an example of how to utilize the two Hubs in this view for transitions.

Since the graph will always choose the shortest path from |one state to another, setting up different transitions from |the Idle and the Move Hub will cause all idle animations to |use a different jump liftoff animation than the walk and the run.

After having fallen for 0.7 seconds, the graph will automatically |choose a different falling animation - since obviously the |character is falling from a greater height.|Once it has entered the "Free Fall" state, it cannot exit through |one of the normal landings.|Instead the landing animation will be a special heavy land, which |also blocks the movement of the character for a second.

Jumping is triggered by the Game Code. It executes a physical impulse and sets the action input to "JumpMP".|Once the code has detected that the character hit solid ground again, it will reset the Action input again and thereby ending the jump.|Note: The code will only reset the Action input if the Action input is still set to either "JumpMP" or "falling".|See the function "IsJumpingOrFallingAGAction" in Player.cpp

The Vehicle Driver Seat is a generic sitting animation fitting for most vehicle types.|To add in a new vehicle, just add a new value to the Input "vehicle". |This state will accept all vehicles that are listed in the Input.||To create a specific's vehicle animation state, clone this one and |change the Selection Criteria for "Vehicle" from "Any Value" to |"Specified Value" and select your vehicle type.||Note that captial and non-capital spelling makes a difference.

Instead of using an LMG for swimming that covers all directions, |swimming is set up with a swim animation for each direction with|discrete selection criteria.|The code executing the swimming is feeding to the graph that he |is swimming, how deep submerged in the water the character is, |and what direction he is swimming.|The graph chooses a fitting animation based on this information.

The Time Alignment Group linked to Walk and Run will make sure |that the animations of these two states are timewarped so that |the footplants match when transitioning from one state into the other.|Since Walk and Run are animations of different lenght, the blending|would otherwise cause artifacts and foot sliding.|The footplant alignment is automatic, either using the animation |length or the footplant mark-up of the animation - if one exists.||See the documentation on how to mark footsteps in an animation if you are using assets with more than two or irregular footfalls.
The facial Sequence modifier here is only an example.|The SDK character currently does not have a facial setup.

FallAndPlay State|This state does not - despite the name - trigger the Fall&Play functionality.|When the code triggers this for example when an AI is knocked down, it |will try to force the graph into a state with this name - hence it should |exist in the graph.||The Wait for Standup Modifier prevents the state from being left before standup is complete.||Corresponding GameDLL Code: |Actor.cpp, search for the line PushForcedState( "FallAndPlay" );
Idle Break Random Animation|This state has a Randomizer set up, the |Animation name is <RandomSet:Random_0>|To see it, select the state and |DOUBLE CLICK on the animation name.||

ParameterizedData.animationName: See AnimationGraph Tutorial 6 in the documentation

AnimationLayer1.animation1: See AnimationGraph Tutorial 6 in the documentation
